content:
advertisement

Helping to implement changes in general education courses continued to be a hot topic with the Penn State Faculty Senate at their first meeting of the year which was held yesterday PERIOD

 senate chair Leonard Berkowitz said PERIOD

Three main issues from last year carrying into senate discussion this year are implementing these changes into general education courses development and evaluation of faculty and reorganization of Commonwealth Campuses PERIOD

Yesterday the General Education Implementation Committee outlined how it would help colleges and departments implement general education courses PERIOD These reports are due to the senate Nov PERIOD  PERIOD

One aspect of assisting faculty with the implementation of new general education courses is consultation PERIOD This includes workshops individual meetings with faculty members or whole departments and a private World Wide Web site for solicitation of comments by faculty to make the process easier PERIOD

 John Bagby chair of GEIC said PERIOD

Three suggestions also were proposed to implement these general education courses PERIOD Providing initial time for academic units to study new designs maintaining ongoing discussions to assess the need for additional faculty and facilities and the continuous refinement of personal development for faculty all were suggested actions PERIOD

 Bagby said PERIOD

Originally GEIC proposed freshman seminar courses would not exceed  students per class PERIOD A committee will review petitions for permission to include more students into these courses PERIOD

Linda Trevino professor of management voiced concern about having more students in a seminar PERIOD

 Trevino said PERIOD 

John Moore vice chair of GEIC agreed he would like to keep the seminar at  students however the implementation would be difficult PERIOD

 he said PERIOD

Eight to nine implementation teams will be set up to help departments faculty and colleges develop the changes and adjustments recommended by GEIC PERIOD
